Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Strike three!

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: Check out Sugar... Puts on twenty pounds in two months; now he's going for twenty more.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: All muscle, baby. Rock solid.

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: Slow down, kid, it ain't going nowhere.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: If you hustled half as much as him, maybe you'd be hungry too.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Fly ball.

Speaker: class
Dialogue: Fly ball.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Line drive.

Speaker: class
Dialogue: Line drive.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Ground ball.

Speaker: class
Dialogue: Ground ball.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Home run!

Speaker: class
Dialogue: Hone rone!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What'd you tell him?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: I told him to grip the ball more gently. Like a tit.

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Pedro Berroa. Third year.     Hasn't developed like we hoped.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: How much he sign for?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Forty-five.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Jesus. These kids keep getting more expensive. How much did you sign for back in the day?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Salvador Torres. Been practicing with the team for almost a week. Still raw, but he's got a lot of potential.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: We gonna sign him?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Soon. Soon. We want to play it low- key, see what his agent says.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: How much you think?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: They've gotten two offers from other clubs. Agent says they were around a hundred.

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: He's good.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What about him?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Miguel Santos. Great arm. We signed him two years ago for fifteen.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Good deal.    He throw any junk?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Sugar!

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Show us your curve.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Not bad.   Mind if I try something?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Hey, kid, do you mind?   May I?

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Give him the ball.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Spike curve. Gives you more rotation, more movement.  You try.

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Vamos!   Let's go! Pitch it!

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It's okay, son, these things take time. You'll figure it out.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: I want to talk to you.

Speaker: class
Dialogue: I want talk to you.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: Your performance in the mound is not as good as last year. What is the problem?

Speaker: class
Dialogue: Your performance in the mound is not good as last year. What is problem?

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe my mechanic.

Speaker: class
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe mechanic.

Speaker: sanchez
Dialogue: I want to give you a chance.   It is up to you...

Speaker: class
Dialogue: I want to give you a chance.   Is up to you...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: How are you, sis?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Any news about the States?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Is that all you have to say?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Hello, Abuela. You're looking beautiful.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What's up my people?   How's the TV?

Speaker: luis
Dialogue: Erica won't let me watch baseball.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Not during American Idol, anyway.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Buenas, Miguelito! Do you have any good news for your mother?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, yes.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: You're going to the United States?!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Not yet, ma... But I learned how to throw a knuckle curve.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: A knuckle curve? What's that?

Speaker: kids
Dialogue: Sugar, come out and play!

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: When will you finish this?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Soon.   It's just hard to find the time.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: It's pretty.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I'm trying to match the chairs my dad made, but I can't get it right.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Well, I think it's perfect.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I'll make you another when I'm done.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: And the rest of the house?   How long till it's done?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Um, another month, maybe two... You know we just did it where Abuela's room is going to be...

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Don't tell me that!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Why not? We can do it in mom's kitchen next. Right over there.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I hope you make it to the States this year.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: You hope? C'mon, there's nobody better, baby.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Okay, how about: I KNOW you'll make it.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Now you're talkin'. And when I do, I'll buy a Cadillac, drive it through the ocean, and bring you back with me.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: You can't drive a Cadillac on water.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Yes! In the States they make cars that drive on water.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: You're crazy.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: You'll see who's crazy.   Just watch.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I want to see the snow.   Does it snow in Kansas City?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I don't know. But I'll take you to New York City. Yankee Stadium. It snows there. You wanta see me play in Yankee Stadium?

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: It doesn't snow during baseball season, silly.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: So we'll go for Christmas.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Promise?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Next Christmas, we'll sail into Yankee Stadium in my Cadillac car-boat. Deal?

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: You are crazy!

Speaker: javier
Dialogue: I liked her, but she asked me to cut my hair. I thought about it. She was cute, but... I liked my hair more.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I liked it too, Javi.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Then why'd you cut it last week?

Speaker: javier
Dialogue: I thought it was time for a new look.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Or a new girl.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Watch it, baby, that's a million-dollar arm you're messing with.

Speaker: javier
Dialogue: He's right!    All hail the golden arm.

Speaker: jaime
Dialogue: You call that flabby rubberband an arm?

Speaker: javier
Dialogue: Oooh...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: This flabby rubberband can throw 95. What can yours do?

Speaker: jaime
Dialogue: I threw 98 in double-A Portland.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: 98? Then why you washing windshields now? I saw you try and bumrush Javy at the stoplight last week.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I like this one. Good bat speed. Only twelve years old, out here four, five hours everyday. His mom tells me he's missing school. I say, yeah, but... have you seen his swing?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm showing his older brother to the Yankees on Monday.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: They don't know what they missed with you. It's cool though. They'll be knocking on your door, offering millions when you turn into a superstar. You'll see...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Have you been to New York?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Nothing like playing for a crowd of New Yorkers. They're even louder than Dominicans.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What's the city like?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: It's great. But you need to get to Kansas City before you start thinking about New York. Know what I mean?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: You hear anything about spring training yet?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Miguel, Luis! Dinner is ready!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: You'd tell me if you knew.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Wanna join us for dinner?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Not tonight. But give your mom a kiss for me, okay?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: C'mon, Nelson! Fire it in, baby!

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: A lot of you are thinking about your families right now. Your girlfriends, sisters and brothers, grandparents. You're feeling the pressure. But, I'm going to tell you something very important, gentlemen... forget it. You've got to think about yourselves. Put all your energy into your game, into your development as a player. Forget about everything else in your life... and just play ball. You wanna succeed, you gotta be like a racehorse, focused on your goal. It's up to you.

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: Next up, Miguel! Here we go!

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: Berroa, see Alvarez when you're dressed.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: So the Dominican's like, `Fuck, what am I gonna do?' He stays there, points up to the sky and says. `Look! There's a plane... Right THERE!'

Speaker: salvador
Dialogue: Hey, Sugar!    They made me an offer.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Good for you. Congratulations.     How much they offer you?

Speaker: salvador
Dialogue: But, you know, my manager's taking, like, forty of it... What'd you sign for?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Oh, you know, more or less the same. Did you get any other offers?

Speaker: salvador
Dialogue: Yankees and Seattle, but not as much.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Just don't get cocky. No one likes a dickhead... Welcome to the team.

Speaker: salvador
Dialogue: So, why do they call you Sugar?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Well it's like this... it started cause I'm sweet with the ladies. But mostly it's cause I got the sweetest knuckle curve in the whole Republic.

Speaker: alfonso
Dialogue: Bullshit! You just learned that shit on Friday! It's cause he eats so much junk food!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: He's just jealous.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: We got you a going away present.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: You should try Los Campos. I heard the Dodgers could use a new first baseman.

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: Fuck that. The coaches are even tougher over there. I'm done, man.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: No caps indoors, son!

Speaker: alfonso
Dialogue: Cut the meat with your knife; eat the meat with your fork. NEVER eat the meat with your knife.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: Or you'll chop off your tongue.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Ten p.m. lights out!

Speaker: pedro
Dialogue: "Tay me outta the ball game, tay me outta the crowd..."

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: Santos, what the hell's wrong with you?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I think I have the flu, coach.    I can't pitch today.

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: You've got five minutes to get out on that mound, Santos.

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: Feel better now? Let's go!

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Strike!

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: Wipe that smile off your face.

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: I am very disappointed. Just when I was starting to like you guys, you go and do something stupid. What do you have to say for yourselves?

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: But Alfonso was there too--

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: --No excuses. This is unacceptable behavior. You guys need to learn discipline.

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: You need to remember that you still have a long way to go, a lot of hard work ahead of you before you make it. First, there's getting your shot in the American Minor Leagues: rookie ball, single, double, triple A - all that before you even set foot in a major league ballpark. So, you better pull it together quick...

Speaker: alvarez
Dialogue: Because nobody's gonna take this shit from a couple Dominican rookies when you go to the U.S. for Spring Training this season.

Speaker: reyes
Dialogue: You've been invited to Spring Training.

Speaker: floor manager
Dialogue: Phone call.    He said it's important.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Don't forget to call everyday.    I want to know everything!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Everything?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: You know what I mean, dummy.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Of course I'll be calling to keep you in check, make sure your grades don't slip.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Look who's talking.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: You are my hero!

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: It was your father's.     I want you to take it with you...

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: You've been   given a wonderful gift, Miguelito.    And God willing, you will continue to   do great things with it. I love you so   much.

Speaker: uncle angel
Dialogue: Miguelito! You gonna remember your uncle Angel when you're all big and famous? Don't forget your family, kid. Never forget where you came from.

Speaker: cousin lupe
Dialogue: Lupe! Cousin Lupe! Remember that time we went skinny-dipping at the Malecn?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: cousing felipe
Dialogue: You were eight years old! Hated the goats so much. You would cry and cry and cry and cry. What a baby you were. Do you remember?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: aunt lola
Dialogue: Lola!   Your aunt Lola!

Speaker: uncle jeffe
Dialogue: Uncle Jeffe!

Speaker: neighbor ana
Dialogue: Your neighbor Ana. I grew up around the corner from here.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Don't give me any shit, kid.      I taught you everything you know.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm damn proud of you, kid.    Your father would be, too.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Thanks.    I owe it all to you.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Not all.   Just forty percent.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I spent the best years of my life playing in the States. Life gives you a lot of opportunities, but baseball only gives you one. Enjoy every minute of it.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: How's your new curve?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: It's pretty sweet.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Good.   Here...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What's this for?

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: Your autograph.

Speaker: frank
Dialogue: I'm kidding, you arrogant prick. It's so you can write your family... and me, too... if you feel like it.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Where's your boyfriend?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Which one?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I don't know; the ugly one.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Hector?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Okay, where's Hector?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Some other party.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: So what about the good-looking one?

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Mmm, Fernando... I think he's out there dancing with Sofia.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I'm proud of you, sis. You're going to do great things too. We all know it.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: I'm gonna miss you...

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: C'mon, let's dance.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Go on, I'll be out in a minute. And tell Fernando to keep his dirty hands off my girl.

Speaker: antonio
Dialogue: Check this out.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: To America!

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: What's up fellas!?

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: Jorge!

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Never, never, never, drink from the hotel mini bar. That shit is expensive. You want beer, buy it at the store. You wanta see titties? They got magazines for that. Don't pay in the hotel.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: You boys ready?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: The greatest thing about the States? You can order breakfast 24/7. French toast is the best. It's nothing like Dominican toast.  French toast please.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Who's next?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Brad Johnson. He just signed for a million dollars out of college.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: There's a lot of guys like that. But you can't let that intimidate you. Everyone knows Dominicans rule the game.

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: What's this about Dominicans ruling the game?

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: No, he must've said Venezuelans.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Sammy, Manny, Pedro...

Speaker: ed
Dialogue: Santana, Zambrano, the Guillens!

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Are you guys all from the same family?

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: Look who's talking... Are these your brothers?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: What, all Dominicans look the same, now?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: This is Miguel and Marcos. Up from Boca Chica.

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: But you couldn't hang in Wichita.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: I injured my knee, asshole.    But I'm healthy now. You'll see.

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: Fifty bucks you're back in Iowa next month.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Fifty bucks you're still an asshole next month.

Speaker: stu
Dialogue: You've gotta show us your best game here. Remember that, until you reach the top, there's always guys above you, hustling to keep you here. And guys below you pushing to take your job. We have 75 pitchers in this camp competing for less than 50 positions come April 3rd. So you gotta work hard...

Speaker: stu
Dialogue: Bring over Leonard.

Speaker: coach
Dialogue: Bring over Leonard!

Speaker: stu
Dialogue: Welcome to America, kid.

Speaker: antonio
Dialogue: I have to admit... I'm getting a little sick of the french toast.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I pitched against Rob Leonard today.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: No shit!   You strike him out?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Liar!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: You don't believe me?

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Well, I got one strike at least.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: So, do you like it there?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Mmmm...    It's different.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: Different how?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I don't know. Just different.     Like the food is really sweet.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I thought you liked sweet things.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: All the players are really good.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: But not like you.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: No, not like me. Of course not... But they're pretty good.

Speaker: sofia
Dialogue: I miss you.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I miss you, too.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: Turn it off.

Speaker: stu
Dialogue: Just relax. Know your pitches. And take it easy. Ground ball. Okay?

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: Just relax. Ground ball.

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Strike!

Speaker: umpire
Dialogue: Two!

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Where did you learn English so good?

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: Back home in Caracas.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Like in high school, or something?

Speaker: orlando
Dialogue: Yeah, but it's still hard though. People talk fast.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: C'mon.    Let's grab some dinner.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Nah, I'm gonna stay and work out a little. I'll catch up later.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Good catch.

Speaker: brad
Dialogue: Thanks... I got lucky.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: French toast, right?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: No...   Egg.    Egg, please.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Eggs. No problem. How would you like'm?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Um, okay, uh... Scrambled?       Over easy? Sunny side up?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: French toast.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: No eggs?   You sure?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: French toast.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Alright, honey. French toast it is.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Okay... This is scrambled.       Scrambled.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Scrambled.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Over easy.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Over easy.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: This one's tricky... Sunny-side-up. Sunny...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Sunny...

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Side...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Side...

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Up...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Up.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Sunny side up... On the house.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: You're welcome.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: They're sending Antonio back.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Shit.   What about you guys?

Speaker: julio
Dialogue: We're staying here.   Rookie ball.

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: Go take a look.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I'm not with you guys?

Speaker: marcos
Dialogue: Straight to Single A, bro.     With Jorge. Congratulations.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Where is Iowa?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Can't I stay with you guys?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Don't worry, Sugar. The Higgins are good people. I stayed with them last time I played here.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Then why don't you stay with them again?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: They have a no girls policy.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Jorge! Good to see you back in Bridgetown!

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Thank you.   This is Miguel.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: I go now.    Take care of my friend.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: We've had Dominicans, Venezuelan boys, a Colombian, one from Panama, blacks and some Americans. Mostly Spanish boys, though. Johan Santana, Mendy Lopez and Ramon Martinez all stayed with us. Years ago.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Last year we had this boy, Junior Sanchez. Nice boy. Decent with the glove, but couldn't bunt to save his life.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Two-for-twelve in sacrifice situations.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Cost the team at least two victories.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh, that's being generous!   I'd say four or five.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Put your things down.   I'll show you around.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: This is the kitchen. Help yourself to whatever you'd like. You can make a list of special foods you like to eat and put it here.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Oh, and over here, this drawer is a little funny.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: You have to be careful or...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: This is the washer and the dryer. For your clothes. You put the soap in this one. Sopa.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Your room is up here.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: El banyo.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Your new cuarto. Bedroom. Do with it as you please. Just no girls. Chicas? No chicas.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: No drinking. No cervezas in the casa. No chicas in the bedroom.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I already told him that one.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Okay.     What about quiet time?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Right. There's no real curfew, but you must be quiet after ten.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Diez.  Shhhh... after diez.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Ten.     Okay.

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Si! That's all we ask. It's our job to keep you healthy and focused on baseball.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: And we take pride in that.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Everyone is so proud, Miguelito.   It's all we can talk about.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Did you get the money?

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Good. And Victor? Can he start construction on the house again? I'll be sending money every two weeks now.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: We just paid him. He's coming next week.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What about you? You get something for yourself like I said?

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Me?   What do I need?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: C'mon, mom...

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: You didn't get anything?

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Well, maybe I got some new shoes, but I'm not telling.

Speaker: erica
Dialogue: Three pairs, Miguel!    But who's counting?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Good for you, mom.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I have to go, mom. The lady is calling me. Smells like dinner.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Dinner? Don't forget who your real mother is, Miguelito. Are you going to prefer her cooking to mine now?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Impossible... I love you, mom.

Speaker: carmen
Dialogue: Everyone loves and misses you.      Strike one out for me, okay?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: Dear Lord... Thank you for the meal we are about to eat. And for blessing us with our new guest. And guiding him safely on his journey from the Dominican Republic to Bridgetown...

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: ...And finally, Lord... Please look kindly over the Swing this season. May all the players stay healthy and... well, why not?... if there's anything you can do to help us win another championship, we'll take that too... Amen.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: So, Miguel... Do - you - eat - meatloaf - back home?

Speaker: helen
Dialogue: I already told you, Michael, he doesn't speak any English.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I know but... I'm curious to know what he thinks of the meatloaf.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: What do you care?   You didn't cook it.

Speaker: hilary
Dialogue: I doubt they have meatloaf in the Dominican Republic, dear.

Speaker: anne
Dialogue: I bet they have something similar. They probably just have another name for it.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: This is good old-fashioned American home cooking, Miguel. Welcome to America.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I like.   Thank you.

Speaker: earl
Dialogue: Well, very good, Miguel. De nada to you, mi amigo. De nada to you.

Speaker: clubby
Dialogue: If you guys ever need tickets for family or friends, just let me know two days ahead of time. Thursday's opener is already sold out, but I saved one row, so you need to speak up now...

Speaker: clubby
Dialogue: Santos - you're over there.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What up, Flaco?

Speaker: brad
Dialogue: Dude, I was totally psyched when I saw your name on the squad. Good times.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Yeah, okay.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: C'mon, bro, let's find you a suit.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I can't afford a suit.

HIGGINS FARMHOUSE - NIGHT                                    103  The car pulls up near the house and Miguel stumbles out, as the wild bunch inside HOOT and HOLLER.  The car backs down the road and the players' voices fade out with the hum of the engine.  An upstairs light goes on. Miguel looks up to the Higgins' bedroom where Helen's silhouetted figure lingers in the window. He tiptoes inside.  The sound of a CHURCH CHOIR fades in, and carries over to...  104   INT. CHURCH - DAY                                                 104  With the exception of Miguel, the all-white congregation sings hymns about Jesus and the Lord. He tries to suppress a yawn when he sees Anne Higgins singing in the choir. She notices him as she sings. A smile.  Miguel perks up.  105   EXT. CHURCH PARKING LOT - DAY                                     105  CHURCHGOERS flood out of the church after the service.    Anne walks alongside Miguel.

Dialogue: Do you know anybody with a room for rent?

Dialogue: You and Jorge used to play baseball together?

Dialogue: Hi, um, do you remember me?

Dialogue: Yeah, but, sorry, I still don't have a job for you.

Dialogue: That's okay. I already found one. I'm actually just trying to make a coffee table, and I'd like to buy some wood and supplies.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: I don't really sell raw materials...

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I just moved here, you know, and I don't have a space to work. Do you think I could do some work for you, help you clean up or whatever you need, in exchange for using your shop? You don't have to pay me.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Somebody paying you for the table?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: No. It's a gift for my mom.   Something I like to do.

Dialogue: How old are you?

Dialogue: Twenty.

Dialogue: Who taught you to make tables?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: My dad.     He was a carpenter in San Pedro.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Is that where you're from?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: I grew up in Santiago.    What are you doing in New York?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I came to work. I used to play baseball.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: The whole world plays baseball. My son's sixteen. Won't touch a piece of wood that's not a bat. I never cared for the game, myself. Too slow.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Your mom still in San Pedro?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Yeah.    With my sister and brother.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: So, you're telling me that you want to make a table for your mom, then mail it back to her in the Dominican?

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Miguel.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Osvaldo.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Hello... Is Sofia at home?... Yeah, it's Miguel again... Can you tell her... Just tell her I called...

Speaker: raquel
Dialogue: You just going to watch or you going to help me out?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Where you from?

Speaker: raquel
Dialogue: Ukraine.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: So you never liked baseball?    Not even as a kid?

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: It's okay. Sometimes during the playoffs I'll watch a game or two.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Who's your favorite player?

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: I don't know enough to have a favorite.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: C'mon, everybody has a favorite player: Juan Marichal, Pedro Martinez?

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Fine.    Jose Canseco.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Jose Canseco!? That's the best you can do?

Dialogue: Okay, what about you?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Roberto Clemente.

Dialogue: Never heard of him.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Shut up.

Dialogue: What's so special about Clemente?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: I read this book where he said something like, "If you have the opportunity to help someone and don't, then you're wasting your life." And he was a carpenter too.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Get out of here.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: For real. He used to make furniture during the off season.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Are you fucking with me? Cause you know I can google this fool right now.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Google?

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: The internet. Don't worry, I'll teach you someday.

Dialogue: When did you get released?

Dialogue: About two weeks ago.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Holy shit.   Where are you staying?

Dialogue: Oh, you know, with a friend. But if you know somebody who needs a roommate...

Dialogue: Why'd you leave?

Dialogue: Do you have any family here?

Dialogue: But I'm okay... I have some money saved, a couple friends. I'll go home to visit soon.

Dialogue: Do you know a place called Ukraine?

Dialogue: I know.    I have tomorrow.   No problem.

Dialogue: Fuck you, man!

Dialogue: What happened to you?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Me?   What happened to you?

Dialogue: I been looking for you for weeks.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: I know. Rafi said you took my old job. Welcome to New York!

Dialogue: I called the Higgins to give my new number, but they said you split. I couldn't believe it, man, I had no idea.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Things got a little ugly after you left.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: We all go through slumps you know.

Dialogue: It wasn't a slump.

Dialogue: I don't know, but I wasn't gonna wait around for them to throw me out.

Dialogue: I'm just saying...

Dialogue: Whatever, man, you wouldn't be saying that shit if you made it.

Dialogue: Sugar! Rafi needs you in the kitchen!

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: They call you Sugar?

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: What can I say? The name sticks.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: They got all kinds in this league, bro. Like fat cats in their forties, kids like you and me, Dominicans, Puerto Ricans, even some white boys. I got this fifty year old catcher on my team, used to play for the Dodgers. Can't run for shit, but he's out there every week. Belly out to here. My man can still go deep though... You ever hear from that kid, Brad?

Dialogue: I did some research and I got a new favorite player now.

Speaker: miguel
Dialogue: Okay, good.

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: Vic Power.    You know him?

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: You ought to. Greatest Puerto Rican first baseman ever. But that's not why he's my favorite player... Back when he first arrived, 1951, 52, he was playing in the minors. Little Rock, Arkansas. So the story goes, one day before a game, Vic stops into this diner for lunch. Hadn't been here long, so he knew very little English. Didn't even notice the "whites only" sign hanging in the window. And Vic was Black. I looked him up on Google. I mean Black like you. So he sits down at the counter and the little waitress comes up to big Vic and says, "I'm sorry, we don't serve colored people."

Speaker: osvaldo
Dialogue: So he leans close to the waitress, tells her in his best English, "That's okay, I don't eat colored people."
